Well, as different as those movies are, Bob Mondello says that none of them sets you up for Eastwood's latest effort: ""Hereafter.
The first seven minutes of ""Hereafter,"" will knock your ears back.
A huge tidal wave - the Indian Ocean tsunami of 2004 - slams into a resort where a French journalist is shopping in a street market.
(SOUNDBITE OF WAVES)
I wish I could say the same thing happens to the sober, heart-felt movie she's in.

After that startling disaster-flick opening, ""Hereafter"" gets hit by a slow-motion tidal wave of afterlife hokum, and you can feel it slipping away, despite Eastwood's best efforts to keep it on life support.
His biggest ally in that struggle is Matt Damon, playing an extremely unwilling psychic who keeps being approached by strangers who want him to do readings - even on the staircase to his apartment.
(SOUNDBITE FROM MOVIE, ""HEREAFTER"")
(as George) I don't do readings anymore.
: (as character) You did one last week for Mr. Andrews.

(as George) I don't want you in...
: (as character) Everything I have.
I lost my only child.
I just want to talk to her.
Please, I want to talk to my baby.
(as George) I - I can't help you.
I don't do that - I don't do it anymore.
Please.
Damon's character is supposed to be the real deal.
When he holds hands with someone, even for just a second, he can see any dead folks they happen to be grieving for.
Understandably, he wears gloves where he can, but sometimes, there's just no avoiding holding hands - say, with a gal he meets in cooking class.
(SOUNDBITE FROM MOVIE, ""HEREAFTER"")

(as George) Because if we open the door and go down that road, any chance that we had of having something normal will just be gone.

I'm Bob Mondello.
Voters in Wisconsin go to the polls next Tuesday.
Democratic presidential hopeful Barack Obama stopped by one of the state's automotive assembly plants yesterday to lay out his economic proposals.
NPR's Scott Horsley reports.
Obama used the GM assembly plant in Janesville, Wisconsin as a symbol of the kind of economy he wants to promote.
For almost 100 years, he said, the plant has produced not just profits for GM, but prosperity for the wider community.
The promise of Janesville has been the promise of America, that our prosperity can and must be the tide that lifts every boat.
That we rise and fall as one nation.
Speaking to a group of blue-collar workers, Obama consciously veered from his inspirational stump speech and tried to anchor lofty ideals with very specific policy proposals.
He recapped a long list of nuts and bolts measures designed to help working families, including tax cuts, affordable health care, and automatic retirement savings.
Obama also called for investing $60 billion over the next 10 years in an infrastructure bank.
He says that would create nearly two million construction jobs - fixing bridges, highways and schools.
And we will fund this bank by ending this war in Iraq.
Obama criticized Hillary Clinton, John McCain and President Bush during his speech.
Clinton fired back, saying Obama's infrastructure proposal and a separate plan to encourage alternative energy jobs are both ideas she raised months ago.
Clinton said during a news conference that American need, quote, ""Real results, not more rhetoric.
Scott Horsley, NPR News.
This is MORNING EDITION from NPR News.
I'm Deborah Amos in for Renee Montagne.
And I'm Steve Inskeep.
As always, White House statements on this issue seem very clear.
The policy of the United States is not to torture.
The president has not authorized it.
He will not authorize it.
That's how White House spokeswoman Dana Perino put it.
But, as always, there's the question: What is the meaning of torture?
Perino's denial came after the New York Times described secret Justice Department memos.
The memos authorize CIA interrogators to use stress positions, extreme temperature, and physical beatings.
NPR's Ari Shapiro is tracking the story.
Ari, good morning.
Good morning.
How significant is it that these New York Times revelations come out just as the Senate is about to consider the president's nominee for attorney general?
It's going to make the confirmation hearings more difficult for Judge Michael Mukasey.
The - Senator Patrick Leahy is the chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, and he basically added this to the list of issues that the White House has not accommodated Congress on.
He asked for memos describing interrogation policies more than a year ago.
The White House has - sorry, it was almost exactly a year ago.
It was November of 2006.
The White House has not obliged.
And yesterday Leahy said those matters now encumber the Mukasey nomination, and as he knows, he will be ask about them.
Rebecca Corenfield says she herself went to dogfights years ago, before she became an animal control officer in Bay City, a rural town an hour outside of Houston.

President Obama speaks at the opening session of the United Nations General Assembly in New York this morning.
We got a sample of the topics he's dealing with during a very busy day yesterday.
He delivered a speech on climate change, he met privately with China's president, and he pressed the Israeli and Palestinian leaders to restart peace talks.
NPR's Don Gonyea reports.
Amid all of the activities surrounding the opening session of the U.N., it seems that President Obama is always front and center.
Yesterday was a day of frenetic activity.
First thing in the morning, his motorcade rolled from the Waldorf Astoria to the U.N.
for the Climate Change Summit.
Then it was back to the hotel for an important set of meetings on the Middle East.
First it was Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, followed by President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority.
